facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 122 to 125 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos, 122 to 125 of 1973. Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petitioner-firm is dealing in the manufacture of automobile parts, wires and cables.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner-firm is dealing in the manufacture of automobile parts, wires and cables.

facts.text: Petitioner made four applications for licences to import stainless steel sheets and electrolytic copper wire bars on November 5,1969, March 23,1970, November 5,1970 and November 6,1970.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner made four applications on November 5,1969, March 23,1970, November 5, 1970 and November 6,1970, for the grant of licences to import stainless steel sheets and electrolytic companyper wire bars, for the period April-March 1970 and April- March 1971.

facts.text: Applications for import licences for the period April-March 1970 and April-March 1971.

anchor.surface_text: for the grant of licences to import stainless steel sheets and electrolytic companyper wire bars, for the period April-March 1970 and April- March 1971.

facts.text: At the time of receipt of first application dated November 5,1969, Respondent 3 received complaints that petitioner-firm was mis-utilizing imported material.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the receipt of the first application dated November 5, 1969, Respondent 3  Deputy Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, Hyderabad  received some companyplaints that the petitioner-firm was mis-utilizing the imported material.

facts.text: CBI made preliminary investigation and registered First Information Report on December 12,1969 against petitioner-firm and others for offences under s.5 of Imports Control Act,1947 read with clause 5 of Imports Control Order,1948.

anchor.surface_text: After a preliminary investigation made by the C.B.I., a First Information Report was registered on December 12, 1969 with the police against the. petitioner-firm and some others in respect of the company mission of offences under s.5 of the Imports  Control  Act, 1947 read with clause 5 of the Imports  Control  Order, 1948.

facts.text: Applications should have been disposed of within three weeks of receipt but respondents did not dispose of them.

anchor.surface_text: In the numbermal companyrse, such applications should have been disposed of within three weeks of the dates on which they were received. Since the respondents did number dispose of the applications,

facts.text: Petitioner filed writ petitions Nos. 3526-3529 of 1971 in High Court of Madras for writ of Mandamus to issue import licences.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner-firm filed four writ petitions  Nos. 3526-3529 of 1971  in the High Court of Madras praying for the issue of writ of Mandamus directing the respondents to issue the import licences applied for.

facts.text: No counter-affidavit filed by respondents before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court, numbercounter-affidavit was filed by the Respondents.

facts.text: High Court directed respondents to consider and dispose of applications expeditiously instead of issuing Mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, instead of issuing a writ of Mandamus, directed the Respondents to companysider and dispose of the applications in accordance with law as expeditiously as possible.

facts.text: Applications not disposed of for another five months after High Court direction.

anchor.surface_text: The applications were however number disposed of for another five months.

facts.text: On September 20,1970, petitioner moved High Court for proceeding against authorities for contempt of its order.

anchor.surface_text: On September 20,1970, the petitioner moved the High Court for proceeding against the authorities for companytempt of its order.

facts.text: On October 22,1972, petitioner served notice by registered post on respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on October 22, 1972, the petitioner caused a numberice by registered post to be served on the respondents.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 informed petitioner by communication dated November 7,1972 that applications rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 then informed the petitioner-firm by his companymunication dated November 7, 1972, that its applications bad been rejected.

facts.text: Reasons for rejection: Stainless steel sheets not allowed for manufacture of automobile parts as import prohibited by existing instructions.

anchor.surface_text: The reasons set out in the impugned orders were  1  Stainless steel-sheets are number allowed for the manufacture of the end product of automobile parts as their import has been prohibited in terms of the 32 3 existing in instructions

facts.text: Reasons for rejection: Import of electrolytic copper wire bars for end use of automobile parts not permissible for petitioner as manufacturer of automobile parts.

anchor.surface_text: 2  Since the petitioner-firm was a manufacturer of automobile parts import of Electrolytic companyper wire bars for end use of automobile parts is number permissible.

facts.text: Petitioners challenge orders of November 7,1972 claiming entitlement under Import Policy in Red Book for relevant period.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners challenge the aforesaid orders of November 7, 1972 passed by the 3rd Respondent, on the ground that in view of the Import Policy companytained in the Red Book for the relevant period,. they were entitled to the grant of these import licences,

facts.text: Serious complaints of commission of criminal offences arising out of mis-utilization of previously imported materials pending investigation by CBI against petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: Serious companyplaints of the companymission of criminal offences arising out of the mis- utilization of materials previously imported under import licences, were pending investigation by the C.B.I. against the petitioners.

facts.text: Criminal complaint filed in court for trial of petitioners and others for those offences.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, a criminal companyplaint has also been made in companyrt for trial of the petitioners and others for those offences.

facts.text: Import Trade Control Policy (Red Book Vol.1) amended prohibiting import of materials for end products of most automobile parts per Chief Controller letter dated September 29,1972.

anchor.surface_text: From the companynter-affidavit filed on behalf of the Respondents, it is clear that the Import Trade Control Policy  Red Book-Vol.1  had been amended and the import of the materials in question for utilization in the end products of most automobile parts was prohibited as per instructions companyveyed by Chief Controller of Imports Exports in his letter No. IPC Gen. 33 /73/72/3499, dated September 29, 1.972

facts.text: General notice of amendment published on August 18,1973.

anchor.surface_text: although general numberice of this amendment was published later on August 18, 1973  Vide Annexure. R-5 .

facts.text: Court finds writ petition by firm maintainable as firm stands for partners who are citizens of India.

anchor.surface_text: We find numbermerit in the preliminary objection that the writ petition on behalf of the firm is number maintainable. Since firm stands for all the partners companylectively, the petition is to be deemed to have been filed by all the partners who are citizens of India.

issues.text: Whether the writ petition filed by the firm is maintainable under Article 32 since Article 19(1)(g) can be availed of only by a citizen of India?

anchor.surface_text: We find no merit in the preliminary objection that the writ petition on behalf of the firm is not maintainable. Since firm stands for all the partners collectively, the petition is to be deemed to have been filed by all the partners who are citizens of India. We, therefore, negative this objection

issues.text: Whether jurisdiction under Article 32 can be invoked for procedural irregularity or error not resulting in violation of or threat to any fundamental right?

anchor.surface_text: jurisdiction of this Court under Article 32 can be invoked only for the enforcement of the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Constitution, and not any other legal right. A petitioner will not be entitled to relief under this Article, unless he establishes that his fundamental right has been violated or imminently threatened.

issues.text: Whether a writ of Mandamus can be issued directing the respondents to grant the import licences as there is no specific legal right or corresponding legal obligation?

anchor.surface_text: No Mandamus or other relief as prayed for by the petitioners, can be granted because the petitioners had no specific legal right to the licences, nor was the Respondent under a corresponding legal obligation to grant the same

issues.text: Whether import licences for the year 1969-70 in respect of the materials in question can be granted despite subsequent restrictions imposed by import Control Policy?

anchor.surface_text: In any case, no import licences for the year 1969-70 in respect of the materials in question can not be granted because of the restrictions subsequently imposed by import Control Policy of the year 1972.

issues.text: Whether the petitioners were entitled to the grant of import licences in view of the Import Policy contained in the Red Book and whether existing instructions could override that policy?

anchor.surface_text: Article 19 of the Constitution on the petitioners right to carry on their trade. The petitioners challenge the aforesaid orders of November 7, 1972 passed by the 3rd Respondent, on the ground that in view of the Import Policy contained in the Red Book for the relevant period, they were entitled to the grant of these import licences, and that the existing instructions on the basis of which their applications were rejected, could not override that Import Policy.

issues.text: Whether the existing instructions amount to unreasonable restrictions within the contemplation of Article 19(1)(g) on the petitioners' right to carry on trade?

anchor.surface_text: Article 19 1 g on which the petitioners stake their claim... In any case, these instructions are unconstitutional they do not amount to reasonable restrictions within the contemplation of Article 19 of the Constitution on the petitioners right to carry on their trade.

issues.text: Whether the impugned refusal to grant licences violated Articles 14 and 19 of the Constitution due to contravention of mandatory procedure in the Import Trade Control Hand Book?

anchor.surface_text: fundamental rights of the petitioners under Articles 14 and 19... Mr. Chitale submits that the Respondents have not followed the mandatory procedure prescribed in the Import Trade Control Hand Book, contravention of which entitles the petitioners to the issue of a writ of Certiorari or any other appropriate order or direction from this Court. This contravention, it is added, has, in effect, violated the fundamental rights of the petitioners under Articles 14 and 19 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the refusal to grant the licences was violative of the rules of natural justice given the pending criminal investigation?

anchor.surface_text: violative of the rules of natural justice... In these circumstances, it could not be said that the disposal of the applications, was delayed by Respondent 3 due to ulterior motives, or that the refusal to grant the licences was violative of the rules of natural justice.

issues.text: Whether there was any hostile discrimination under Article 14?

precedents.cited_proposition: Jurisdiction under Article 32 can only be invoked for enforcement of fundamental rights, not other legal rights; procedural irregularities do not invoke Article 32 unless they violate fundamental rights
precedents.cited_holding: A petitioner is not entitled to relief under Article 32 unless fundamental right is violated; categories of violation in administrative actions under trade laws

precedents.citation: Deputy Assistant Iron and Steel Controller and anr. v. L. Maneckchand, Proprietor, Katrella Metal Corpn., Madras.  1

anchor.surface_text: The nature of such a claim came up for consideration before this Court in Deputy Assistant Iron and Steel Controller and anr. v. L. Maneckchand, Proprietor, Katrella Metal Corpn., Madras.  1  That was an appeal by special leave against the judgment of tile High Court rendered in exercise of writ jurisdiction under Art. 226.

precedents.case_name: Deputy Assistant Iron and Steel Controller v. L. Maneckchand
precedents.cited_proposition: No vested or fundamental right to import licence based on policy statement at time of application; policy can be changed; no mandamus for delay not due to authority's fault; imports must be controlled for economy
precedents.cited_holding: In view of s.3(1)(a) of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 and cl.6(1)(a) of the Imports Control Order, 1955, an applicant has no vested right to an import licence in terms of the policy in force at the time of the application.
